What’s in a Story?

April 04, 2017

About a week ago, many Facebook users opened up their application on their smartphone, and noticed a very different change.  While regular updates are pretty common with Facebook (I don’t know if anyone remembers how horrible it was to use Facebook on mobile when smartphones and app stores started gaining popularity), not many of the updates are noticeable, mainly just changes under the hood for user experience.  Facebook added a “Story” mode.

If you are not social media savvy, the Story was originally created and made popular by Snapchat.  A Story is basically a short form video, 10-15 seconds at most, depending on the platform, that disappears in 24 hours.  While Snapchat started the Story trend, Instagram was quick to jump in and now, most recently Facebook has joined the band wagon, and I’m sure Twitter and other social networks are not too far behind.  But why are the creators of these sites adding these features?  What’s the big deal about a social network Story?

Where did the Story Come From?

A lot of this can be contributed to the rise of video in social media, and not just the refined, polished videos brands post to Youtube and share across their networks.  Live format videos rose in popularity synonymously with the start of Story sharing.

For brands, the idea of engaging fans with behind the scene clips that you either can only see through the live video, which also allows for engagement via comments while the video is live.  This engagement can be taken one step farther by showing the day to day workings of a brand, through still pictures or videos that disappear in 24 hours, and thus free up much more time then doing a live video would, and can reach more people because they do not have to be online at the exact moments that a video is live to engage.

In all of the different site’s versions of the Story, they are exclusively available on the mobile platform, screen shots can be shared directly with others, often notifying the content creator, or as a way to to start a direct message with the creator themselves. Spurts of behind the scenes and day to day lives that are short, sweet, and very easily digestible.

Seems like a pretty winning formula to me.  We will probably see Twitter use their periscope platform to join in on the fun before too long as well. Besides the obvious behind the scenes looks at a brand, stories can be used for a ton of different marketing implications, such as:

  • Offering coupons and discounts
  • Premiering new products and offerings and showing demos
  • Holding contests
  • Promoting events
  • Encouraging users to join your email list
  • For local users, create a scavenger hunt

The possibilities are endless, and using a Story is another great way to connect a brand with their audience, and further engage and personalize your product or brand.
